title: Brimham Rocks Walk Route

images.title: Elliott Simpson / Brimham Rocks, Nidderdale.
images.caption: Climbers on the rocks. The National Trust site says there is "Rock climbing for the more experienced" - these climbers look very relaxed.

images.title: Gordon Hatton / 'The Dancing Bear' Brimham Rocks
images.caption: 'The Dancing Bear', Brimham Rocks, in the snow. Several of the rocks at Brimham have fanciful names. Some [like the Idol] are easily spotted, whilst some imagination is required to find the less obvious ones. The names largely date from Victorian times when the rocks became a popular excursion from Harrogate.

images.title: Geertivp, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The rocks known as the turtle and eagle

images.title: Sleeping dinosaur - Brimham Rocks by Tom Howard, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Sleeping dinosaur

images.title: David Rogers / Brimham House
images.caption: Brimham House. Now the visitor centre.

images.title: Paul Gillett / Tracks around Brimham Rocks
images.caption: Benches and footpath with a view over Nidderdale from the site.

images.title: Trig Point, Brimham Rocks by Mark Anderson, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Trig Point

description: Brimham Rocks is a National Trust owned site with a collection of fascinating rock formations. You can explore the labyrinth of paths while enjoying fabulous views over Nidderdale. This circular walk starts from the on site car park where you can pick up trails heading around Brimham Moor where there's pretty heather to see. The trails will take you around the ancient rocks which are hundreds of millions of years old. It's also great for wildlife with a number of bird boxes attracting Blue Tits and Redstarts to nest in the area. The site is located near Pateley Bridge and on the Nidderdale Way walking route so there is scope for continuing your walk through the Nidderdale AONB.
